imageAlt: Anterior view of the human chest.
stem: The nurse is auscultating the anterior chest. Which location corresponds to the Right Upper Lobe?

rationale.correct: The Right Upper Lobe is best auscultated anteriorly in the area above the clavicle down to the 4th rib on the right side of the chest.
rationale.incorrect: The Left Upper Lobe (h2) is on the patient's left side. The Right Middle Lobe (h3) is lower, typically auscultated between the 4th and 6th ribs on the right side.
clinicalPearls: The right upper lobe is a common site for aspiration pneumonia in supine patients.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The patient's right is on the left side of your screen in an anterior view.

mnemonic.title: R-U-L
mnemonic.expansion: Right Upper Lobe = Right High Lobe.

imageAlt: Anterior view of the pelvis and upper thigh.
stem: The nurse needs to assess the femoral pulse during CPR in an adult. Click on the correct location.

rationale.correct: The femoral pulse is located in the groin, midway between the symphysis pubis and the anterior superior iliac spine, just below the inguinal ligament. It is a large, central pulse accessible during resuscitation.
rationale.incorrect: The lateral hip (h2) contains the greater trochanter and gluteal muscles but no major palpable arteries. The Pubic Symphysis (h3) is the midline bony junction of the pubic bones.
clinicalPearls: The femoral artery is medial to the femoral nerve and lateral to the femoral vein (NAVEL: Nerve, Artery, Vein, Empty space, Lymph).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't click the pubic bone; the artery is lateral to the bone in the soft tissue space.

mnemonic.title: N-A-V-E-L
mnemonic.expansion: Nerve, Artery, Vein (from Lateral to Medial).

stem: The nurse assesses circulation to the foot. Click on the location of the Posterior Tibial Pulse.

rationale.correct: The posterior tibial pulse is palpated in the groove behind and slightly below the medial malleolus (the inner ankle bone).
rationale.incorrect: The dorsum of the foot (h2) is where the dorsalis pedis pulse is found. The heel (h3) is a fatty/bony area where pulses are not palpable.
clinicalPearls: The posterior tibial pulse can sometimes be easier to find than the dorsalis pedis pulse in patients with edema.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Top of the foot is Dorsalis Pedis; the Posterior Tibial is specifically at the inner ankle.

mnemonic.title: P-T
mnemonic.expansion: Posterior to the Tibial bone edge.

reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with vascular. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: A client has suspected splenomegaly. The nurse should palpate which quadrant gently to assess the spleen?

rationale.correct: The spleen is located in the Left Upper Quadrant (LUQ), tucked under the rib cage. In cases of splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), it must be palpated very gently to avoid the risk of rupture.
rationale.incorrect: The Right Upper Quadrant (h2) contains the liver. The Left Lower Quadrant (h3) contains the descending and sigmoid colon.
clinicalPearls: A normal-sized spleen is usually not palpable.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Spleen = Left, Liver = Right. They are opposites in the upper quadrants.

mnemonic.title: S-L-U-Q
mnemonic.expansion: Spleen in the Left Upper Quadrant.

imageAlt: Posterior view of the human back showing spine and ribs.
stem: The nurse is assessing for kidney infection (pyelonephritis). Click on the area where the nurse percusses for Costovertebral Angle (CVA) tenderness.

rationale.correct: The Costovertebral Angle (CVA) is the angle formed by the 12th (last) rib and the vertebral column. Percussing over this area elicits sharp pain if the underlying kidney is inflamed (pyelonephritis, stones).
rationale.incorrect: The area over the scapula (h3) is too superior and overlies the lungs, not the kidneys. Direct percussion on the spine itself is also not for CVA assessment.
clinicalPearls: Use indirect percussion (place one hand flat and strike it with the ulnar side of the other fist) to assess for CVA tenderness.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't click directly on the vertebrae; go just lateral into the muscular angle.

stem: The nurse is palpating the carotid pulse. Click on the correct location.

hotspots.label: Groove between Trachea and SCM Muscle

rationale.correct: The carotid pulse is palpated in the groove just medial to the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle and lateral to the trachea.
rationale.incorrect: The Trachea (h2) is the central airway containing cartilaginous rings. The lateral neck muscles (h3) are too far away from the major cervical vessels.
clinicalPearls: Avoid palpating both carotid arteries at the same time, as this can severely restrict blood flow to the brain and trigger bradycardia via the carotid sinus reflex.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never palpate both sides simultaneously; it can cause brain ischemia or reflex bradycardia.

mnemonic.title: C-C
mnemonic.expansion: Carotid in the Canal (between airway and muscle).

stem: Click on the location where the temporal artery pulse is assessed.

rationale.correct: The temporal artery is palpated on the temple, anterior to and slightly above the ear tragus, overlying the temporal bone.
rationale.incorrect: The Mandible (h2) is the lower jawbone. The Occipital area (h3) is the back of the head.
clinicalPearls: Assess the temporal artery for tenderness and thickening in patients suspected of having Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't go down to the mandible; stay up on the temporal bone.

imageAlt: Posterior view of the upper arm.
stem: The nurse is administering a subcutaneous injection to an adult. Click on the appropriate site on the upper arm.

rationale.correct: The posterior aspect of the upper arm (over the triceps) contains sufficient subcutaneous fat for injections and is a standard site for vaccines like the MMR or insulin administration.
rationale.incorrect: The Shoulder area (h2) is the site for deltoid IM injections. The Elbow (h3) is a bony joint with no subcutaneous tissue for injection.
clinicalPearls: Pinch the skin to separate the subcutaneous tissue from the underlying muscle before injecting.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Don't go into the deltoid (shoulder) for subcutaneous meds; the triceps area has more fat.

reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with injection. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a Mantoux Tuberculin Skin Test (PPD). Click on the correct injection site.

rationale.correct: The anterior (volar) aspect of the forearm is the preferred site for intradermal injections like the PPD. The skin is thin and usually hairless, which facilitates observing the formation of a wheal and reading the results 48-72 hours later.
rationale.incorrect: The Antecubital fossa (h2) contains major veins and is too vascular for intradermal testing. The Wrist (h3) has thin skin and prominent tendons, making intradermal injection difficult.
clinicalPearls: Insert the needle at a 5-15 degree angle, bevel up, until the wheal (bleb) forms.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Avoid the antecubital veins; find a clear, hairless, flat area of skin.

imageAlt: Top-down view of an infant's head.
stem: The nurse is assessing a 4-month-old infant for dehydration. Click on the location of the anterior fontanelle.

rationale.correct: The diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle is located at the top of the infant's head where the frontal and parietal bones meet. A sunken fontanelle is a significant clinical find indicating dehydration.
rationale.incorrect: The posterior fontanelle (h2) is triangular and smaller, located toward the back of the head; it typically closes much earlier (by 2 months). The forehead (h3) is solid bone (frontal bone).
clinicalPearls: A bulging fontanelle when the infant is not crying may indicate increased intracranial pressure.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: The anterior fontanelle is diamond-shaped and larger; the posterior is triangular and tiny.
